repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Introduce a new `MarkSet` autocommand that is called after a mark is set. Closes #27896.

Here it is in action. My config looks like this:

```lua
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd("MarkSet", {
  desc = "Print when a mark is set",
  callback = function(ev)
    print(vim.inspect(ev))
  end,
})
```

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/94703741-2683-496b-9f31-d0afad82ed1f

If this PR is merged and there's interest, I'd also like to contribute a similar `MarkDeleted` autocommand.

Note that `mark.c` doesn't seem to have any direct unit tests. Is `test/functional/autocmd/` the best dir to add tests to? This is my first real PR to Neovim so I'm not super familiar with the testing practices.

comment_data.body:
for better or worse, the common convention is `do_autocmd_`
```suggestion
static bool do_autocmd_markset(char c, pos_T *pos, buf_T *buf)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -89,6 +91,24 @@ void clear_fmark(fmark_T *const fm, const Timestamp timestamp)
   fm->timestamp = timestamp;
 }
 
+/// Execute "MarkSet" autocommand.
+///
+/// @param c The name of the mark, e.g., 'a'.
+/// @param pos Position of the mark in the buffer.
+/// @param buf The buffer of the mark.
+///
+/// @return true if the autocommand was executed.
+static bool apply_markset_autocmd(char c, pos_T *pos, buf_T *buf)

comment_regular_data.body:
Hmm, it looks like `functionaltest` and `oldtest` are complaining about memory leaks. @bfredl do you have any idea where the memory leak might be coming from? I'd assume it's something in `apply_markset_autocmd` but I couldn't find anything obvious.

Also the `lint` failure looks to be unrelated to this change but let me know if that's not the case.

Once we figure out the memory leak, I can squash these commits down into a conventional commit!
`cchar_to_string()` allocates memory, so you can't use that. In fact the only use of `cchar_to_string()` was removed in 5d6987210578f5f1c3151988b99a9411f9603374 in favor of `cstr_as_string()`.
Memory leak has been fixed, commits have been formatted. @bfredl this is ready for review!
@bfredl just wanted to check - any FUD about this PR?

The main reason that new autocmds are a pain is because they execute code in completely random places where it's not expected that user-defined vimscript can be executed. For example, here you have added several new places in the middle of `setmark_pos` that now can just execute any user code.

I wonder if we can start following a different approach #35366 : instead of immediately executing the autocmd handlers, set the state for the autocmd but don't execute handlers until a known safe-state. To unblock you, that could be here perhaps: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/7eb9badd9384ee5970245e2c6f25f170dea91ce8/src/nvim/state.c#L298-L308

This will require you, in this PR, to write the code that we would use for this pattern going forward. Initially, this pattern will only apply to MarkSet, but would be re-used for other events in the future.

WDYT @neovim/core ?

Haven't vetted this, so no idea what the actual impact is, but from a quick skim I see places like `win_fix_cursor` assuming `wp` remains valid after `setmark` (which calls into `setmark_pos`), or `ex_mark` assuming `curwin` is unchanged when restoring the cursor; autocommands could mess with all of that.

I'm a fan of the idea of deferring newer events; infinitely better than adding new hacks and ineffective locks all over the place. I see some value in being able to react immediately though, like overriding a mark's position immediately after its set, plus `SafeState` specifically might be too deferred as it doesn't trigger during mappings for example (nor in all modes).

> `SafeState` specifically might be too deferred as it doesn't trigger during mappings for example (nor in all modes).

good point. then, some other place at the "top" of the event-loop.

> I see some value in being able to react immediately though, like overriding a mark's position immediately after its set,

"immediately" could be "the next time we're about to execute user code". anything more "immediate" than that is just out of scope.
FYI, please do not add merge commits to PR's. Can you rebase and/or squash?
Closing this out until we implement #35366

While waiting on #35366, are there any good workarounds to trigger logic on mark creation? It seems like all the "marks in the signcolumn" just wrap the `m` keymaps and store a table of mark locations - but this makes it easy to accidentally desync state if you use the command interfaces.

> are there any good workarounds to trigger logic on mark creation? 

none that I could find. "marks in the signcolumn" is also my motivation for this PR. I've been quite busy with a move recently, but hoping to get some time to work on #35366 later this week.

title: feat(marks): Add `MarkSet` autocmd
